title: Ticket #7733: Improve job id validation checks
description:
The schedd has poor validation of job ids for SetAttribute() and DeleteAttribute() qmgmt calls. If the job id isn't a valid key in the committed job queue log, it assumes the ad has been created in the active transaction (if any). It rejects the attribute modification unless the cluster id matches active_cluster_num and the proc id is less than next_proc_num. When submitting a new cluster, this allows SetAttribute() of arbitrary negative proc ids. When not submitting a new cluster, this allows SetAttribute() of cluster id -1 with arbitrary negative proc ids.

The actions are logged in job_queue.log, but don't appear to affect the in-memory queue (since the ads don't actually exist). When the log is compressed, the errant entries disappear (since they aren't in the in-memory version). The only practical effects appear to be that the SetAttribute() and DeleteAttribute() calls succeed, and the Job Router will report errors when reading the log.

We are making the following changes to improve the code that validates SetAttribute() and DeleteAttribute() calls:

  • Change TotalSubmitProcs from immutable to secure and remove the special exception for it.
  • Reject all modification of nonexistent job ids by default, even for calls internal to the schedd.
    • Use of the NONDURABLE flag is no longer required to detect an invalid job id, which the dedicated scheduler was relying on.
    • Submit transforms and late materialization are exempted from this check. They may need to modify ads created in the active transaction that would be rejected by our heuristic for allowed in-transaction edits (examining active_cluster_num and next_proc_num). They are internal code and assumed trustworthy. We could remove this exemption if we had an efficient way to check a job id against all of the ids created in the active transaction.
remarks:
2020-Jul-23 13:04:18 by zmiller:
Found a couple other surprises when messing around. 256.0 is a valid job in the queue. 
% condor_qedit 256.-250 foo 1
Set attribute "foo" for 1 matching jobs.

% condor_qedit 256.-25000000000000000 foo 1
Set attribute "foo" for 1 matching jobs.

% condor_qedit 256.-2500000000000000000000000 foo 1
Failed to set attribute "foo" for job 256.1.
Queue transaction failed.  No attributes were set.

% condor_qedit 256.9223372036854775807 foo 1
Set attribute "foo" for 1 matching jobs.

% condor_qedit 256.9223372036 foo 1
Failed to set attribute "foo" for job 256.633437444.
Queue transaction failed.  No attributes were set.

2020-Jul-23 13:56:33 by jfrey:
When there's no qmgmt client, SetAttribute() will approve setting of attributes for non-existent job ids. The record is written to the job_queue.log, but is ignored in-memory. A caller in the schedd can opt into checking whether the job id exists by using the NONDURABLE flag. The dedicated scheduler depends on the this to set the attribute Scheduler for all jobs in a given cluster. It calls SetAttribute() with NONDURABLE with increasing procids until a failure is returned.

This very non-obvious behavior can be cleaned up if SetAttribute() has a proper check for non-existent job ids.

2020-Jul-23 13:59:22 by jfrey:
About Zach's surprising qedits: It appears condor_qedit ignores "bogus" procids and pretends they weren't given. It then does an edit of the entire cluster by constraint. Negative values and overly-large values (possibly just ones that overflow to a negative value) are "bogus".

2020-Jul-27 15:55:55 by jfrey:
Some additional candidates for cleanup in the SetAttribute() validation code:

  • Instead having ATTR_TOTAL_SUBMIT_PROCS be an immutable attribute and having a special case exception for late materialization to modify it, it should be a protected or secure attribute.
  • Extend the restriction on modifying cluster 0 to also reject modifying negative cluster ids.

2020-Nov-10 14:28:43 by jfrey:
This ticket should have no user-visible effects, so I'm not making a version history entry.

2020-Nov-10 14:30:53 by zmiller:
Does this need to stay private? I.e. did you identify any security risks while working on this code?

2020-Nov-10 14:32:53 by jfrey:
No, it doesn't need to be private.
